channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Gains Against ISIS Bring More Deaths Elsewhere in Iraq
item.description: Following the liberation of Ramadi, Baghdad has experienced a return to the days when guerrilla tactics paralyzed the city.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Residents left their homes on the outskirts of Ramadi on Friday as Iraqi security forces worked to clear the area in the wake of declaring victory against the Islamic State, whose fighters had planted thousands of roadside bombs and booby traps.

item.title: Gunmen Stage Deadly Siege on Burkina Faso Hotel
item.description: Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa claimed responsibility for the attack on a hotel popular with Westerners in the capital. The episode left dozens dead, according to reports.
item.dc:creator: THIBAULT BLUY, DIONNE SEARCEY and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: A Burkina Faso soldier near the Splendid Hotel, where an attack was continuing in Ouagadougou on Friday.

item.title: Addressing Critics, White House Cites Diplomacy in Release of Sailors by Iran
item.description: As some characterized the seizure of American patrol boats as a foreign policy failure, the Obama administration said the quick release of the sailors was a benefit of nuclear diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An image released on Wednesday by Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps showed United States sailors in Iranian custody. They were let go, unharmed, after 14 hours.

item.title: German Town Bars Male Asylum Seekers From Its Public Pool
item.description: The town of Bornheim made the move after receiving complaints that some women were sexually harassed at the pool, with officials saying that breaching German cultural norms was a red line that should not be crossed.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Ousted Communist Official’s Brother Is Living in United States, China Says
item.description: Beijing is said to be in discussions with Washington about the brother of Ling Jihua, a former party official who is awaiting trial on graft charges.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ling Wancheng’s home in Loomis, Calif. He and his wife bought a 7,800-square-foot home from a professional basketball player in 2013.

item.title: Venezuela Declares Emergency as Its Economy Falters
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro is seeking additional powers to bypass the National Assembly on spending matters, but the measure would have to be approved by the president’s rivals.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: China Embraces Craft Beers, and Brewing Giants Take Notice
item.description: Chinese consumers are swapping mass-produced local beers for a bevy of imports and locally brewed brands, and a merged Anheuser-Busch InBev-SABMiller aims to capitalize.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG and CAO LI
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Jing-A Brewing Taproom in Beijing serves American-inspired beers with local flare, including Worker’s Pale Ale and Airpocalypse Double IPA.

item.title: News Analysis: Starvation in Syria Galvanizes U.N., but Accountability Seems Distant as Ever
item.description: Despite renewed attention to the use of starvation as a weapon of war by the Syrian government and rebels alike, accountability is arguably more elusive.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: To Protect Against Zika Virus, Pregnant Women Are Warned About Latin American Trips
item.description: Pregnant women are told to avoid countries where mosquitoes are spreading the virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Dejailson Arruda with his daughter, Luiza, in Capibaribe, Brazil. Thousands of babies in the country have been born with a birth defect that has been linked to the spread of Zika virus.

item.title: To Protect Against Zika Virus, Pregnant Women Are Warned About Latin American Trips
item.description: Pregnant women are told to avoid countries where mosquitoes are spreading the virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: For Now, Anglicans Avert Schism Over Gay Marriage
item.description: A truce was achieved when archbishops at a meeting in England voted resoundingly to impose restrictions for three years on the church’s American province, the Episcopal Church.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: A protest at the Canterbury Cathedral in England on Friday.

item.title: Day After a Victory Over Ebola, Sierra Leone Reports a Death
item.description: A 22-year-old woman from the northern part of the country was identified as the victim, and certain areas would be quarantined in response to her death.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and SHERI FINK
item.media:description: A man checked temperatures and helped wash people’s hands as they left an Ebola quarantined area in the village of Massessehbeh, on the outskirts of Freetown, Sierra Leone, in August.

item.title: In New Year’s Melee in Cologne, a Migrant Was One Woman’s Savior
item.description: Unlike other women in Cologne, Germany, on New Year’s Eve, who said they were sexually assaulted by migrants, Caitlin Duncan says she was rescued by them.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Live Updates: Attack at Hotel in Burkina Faso's Capital
item.description: A gun battle broke out outside the Splendid Hotel in Burkina Faso’s capital, Ouagadougou, on Friday night. The hotel, in the business district of Ouagadougou, is frequented by Westerners.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: E.U.’s Open Borders Are in Danger, German Minister Warns
item.description: Finance Minister Wolfgang Schäuble said the migrant crisis posed a threat to free travel within the European Union as border restrictions tighten.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants on the Greek island of Lesbos in November. The Greek coast is a common arrival point for migrants who then move north in the hope of gaining asylum in countries like Germany and Sweden.

item.title: 6 Hospitalized, One of Them Brain-Dead, After Drug Trial in France
item.description: The drug was being tested on healthy volunteers in a licensed private institution specializing in clinical trials, the health minister said.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.media:description: Six men have been hospitalized during Phase 1 of clinical trial by Biotrial, a drug-evaluation company based in Rennes, France.

item.title: Sean Penn Says His El Chapo Article ‘Has Failed’
item.description: In an interview with CBS to be broadcast on Sunday, Mr. Penn said he had hoped his interview with the fugitive would lead to a debate about the drug war.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.media:credit: Emily Berl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sean Penn at an event he put on to raise money for the Haitian Relief Organization on Saturday. He spoke with CBS on Thursday about his meeting with the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera.

item.title: Portugal to Extradite Ex-C.I.A. Agent to Italy in Rendition Case
item.description: Former C.I.A. agent has denied involvement in the kidnapping of a Egyptian cleric in 2003, which took place while she was working undercover as a diplomat in Milan.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Barbara L. Salisbury/McClatchy Company and Tribune Company, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The former C.I.A. agent Sabrina De Sousa at her home in Washington in 2013. She says she is working on a book that is “going to be the story of going through this whole business of trying to clear my name.”

item.title: El Chapo’s Affection for Actress Is Met With Mockery Online
item.description: In facetious posts on Twitter and other social media sites, some commenters speculated on the intentions of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera toward the actress Kate del Castillo.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Giorgio Gomelsky, Impresario Who Gave the Rolling Stones Their Start, Dies at 81
item.description: Mr. Gomelsky, who was born on a ship going from Ukraine to Italy, also worked with the Yardbirds early in their career.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Giorgio Gomelsky at his rehearsal and performance space in Manhattan in 2013.
